awd_titl_txt: Settlement System and Landscape Dynamics: An Integrated Archaeological and Geomorphological Study
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the National Science Foundation, Drs. Jeffrey Clark and Donald Schwert will lead a multidisciplinary team in research designed to address critical issues of human migration, colonization, and subsequent cultural development in the central Pacific. Undertaken from the perspective of human ecodynamics, this project is a case study of an island environment and its prehistoric human occupation that bears on larger questions of human-environment co-evolutionary relationships. Integrated archaeological, osteological, geomorphological, and pedological studies will investigate the complex, dynamic relationships between human populations and their environments on the island of Ofu, Manu'a Group, American Samoa.  The project will provide tests of core elements of the conventional model of central Pacific prehistory and the origin of Polynesian peoples.  

The conventional model holds that the colonists of central Polynesia were Lapita peoples from islands to the west. "Lapita" refers to a people or group of peoples that shared a "cultural complex" for which a distinctive dentate-stamped pottery is diagnostic.  Lapita colonizers came to the region perhaps 3000 BP and were farmers and fishers who relied heavily on exchange of valued resources between communities. Since Lapita populations were the first to arrive in the Central Pacific, they are regarded as ancestral to later Polynesian populations.  

Some researchers are increasingly calling this model into question on a set of issues, and Samoa is strategically situated in terms of both geographic location and previous research to allow for critical tests of those issues.  Project investigations will be conducted at three locations on Ofu shown to possess, or hold potential for, early cultural deposits: Va'oto, Coconut Grove, and Ofu Village. Because landscape change influenced settlement systems, geomorphological modeling of the paleo-landscapes will be carried out in conjunction with excavations. The project has four objectives: 1) establish the time of human colonization; 2) construct and test models of the human settlement distribution; 3) test a set of models for landscape evolution; and 4) construct a model of the geomorphological dynamics of the Ofu coast.  Each objective will be addressed through the testing of a set of hypotheses. 

The intellectual merit of the project lies in the intersection of archaeological, biological, geological, and pedological evidence to evaluate multiple working models of island colonization and subsequent adaptation.  The overarching goal is to construct a new model of the human colonization and subsequent settlement system in the context of a changing environment during the first millennium BC.  This model will have applicability to coastal environments on other islands throughout the central Pacific.  The results of the research will make an important contribution to the understanding of Samoan and Polynesian prehistory, human prehistory and colonization impacts more generally, and human ecodynamics in the broadest sense. 

Through the conduct of "community archaeology," local community members will be engaged with the scientific team to create cultural heritage knowledge relevant for professional and local stakeholders, alike. The project will serve to educate graduate and undergraduate students from the US, American Samoa, and Independent Samoa, many of whom are from backgrounds underrepresented in the sciences.

por.por_cntn:
Human migration and the colonization of new lands is a hallmark of the human experience, beginning with first spread of human ancestors out of Africa.  The last, and arguably most impressive, great migration was the spread of humans throughout Oceania, that vast expanse of the Pacific Ocean with widely separated islands and island groups.  Beginning about 3,500 years ago, a major thrust took people with what is called Lapita culture to the islands of the Central Pacific where, in the archipelagoes of Tonga and Samoa, ancestral Polynesian culture eventually evolved before a final push out to the far-flung islands of central and eastern Polynesia. That remarkable migration has remained a subject of great interest not just to Oceanic archaeologists but to all who study human migration, colonization, and adaptation processes. Another long-standing interest of archaeologists has been the systemic relationships between humans and their environment, and the role of human actions in altering – both intentionally and unintentionally – ecosystems. The arrival of humans in “pristine” environments of previously unoccupied islands has been of particular interest because it is in such conditions that the impact of human colonization might be studied most effectively.  

Examples of human colonization of pristine, isolated environments can be seen in the islands of the Samoan Archipelago of West Polynesia. The research reported here is a case study of one such island: Ofu, in the Manu'a Group of the U.S. Territory of American Samoa. Our study was an integrated archaeological and geomorphological study of the complex, dynamic relationships between human populations and their environments. Our primary focus was on the colonization of the island by early migrants, the landscape and environment they encountered, the human adaptation to the island, and the changes that took place in both human behaviors and the natural environment. Those data were taken in conjunction with other geoarchaeological studies on Ofu and nearby islands by the Principal Investigators and others in order to arrive at a broader and deeper understanding of the island’s prehistory.

The investigation was carried out by way of archaeological excavations at three coastal sites identified as likely locations of initial colonization based on geomorphological (landscape) conditions and potential availability of food and other resources. We also undertook aerial and ground survey of selected areas of the island's uplands and interior. We collected a broad range of data, including the probable date of arrival on the island, the types of artifacts people made, and the relationship of those settlers to people on other islands in the Central Pacific, particularly Lapita. Other data revealed aspects of how they lived, such as the foods they ate and how they utilized the landscape. We also gathered evidence on how the landscape changed over time due to both natural conditions (e.g., change in sea level) and human impacts (e.g., population growth, pressure on resources, and landscape alterations). In short, the settlement and subsistence systems on the island were dynamic and changed significantly over time.  A very brief summary of the model we have constructed of those changes is as follows. 

People first arrived in about 700 B.C. They did not carry typical Lapita artifacts, so their relationship to the Lapita wave of migration is unclear. For several centuries they lived in small communities on the coast, moving to different locations around the island periodically to focus on locally available resources. Eventually, they may have settled permanently in one or more small villages.  With population growth, people began moving from the coast to the island’s uplands where farming was more productive. Clearing vegetation for farming led to soil erosion (high rainfall on steep slopes) and redeposited soils in the lowlands and out onto the reef, thus decreasing marine resources. That process accelerated the move away from the coast and to the uplands, and the expansion of farming to feed an ever-growing population. Other factors were involved in that settlement shift as well, such as a likely increase in warfare as the political systems in the islands grew more complex. Climate changes were undoubtedly taking place over the centuries, and it is possible that a period of increased tropical storminess contributed to making coastal living precarious at times. Only much later, about the time of European contacts in the islands, did the population move back to the coast, abandoning the upland settlement.

In summary, as a result of the project, we have been able to construct a new model of the settlement and subsistence patterns that developed from initial colonization at around 2700 years ago to the time of European exploration of the Pacific and the Western “discovery” of Samoa. As with all models, ours is provisional (subject to revision with new data), but it serves as a tool for studying and understanding the processes of colonization, adaption to variable environments, and human-environment interactions.
